div.p: A HERMIT'S TALE: RECORDED BY HIS OWN HAND, AND FOUND IN HIS CELL.

q.l: There oft is found an Avarice in Grief;
And the wan Eye of Sorrow loves to gaze
Upon the ſecret Hoard of treaſur'd Woes.

div.p: LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. CADELL, IN THE STRAND. M.DCC.LXXXVII.

div.head: RICHARD BRINSLEY SHERIDAN, Eſq.
div.p: EQUALLY induced by a juſt admiration of your talents, and a grateful ſenſe of the diſtinction your praiſe has given to thoſe you were pleaſed to find in me, permit me to ſolicit your further indulgence to this little production; and be aſſured, its greateſt value in my eyes is, that it ſerves to convey thoſe acknowledgments, with which I have the honour to remain,

closer.signed: Your moſt obliged, Obedient humble ſervant, SOPHIA LEE.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FROM prime of youth to hoary age
In this lone cell I've dwelt;
Here ſought, by tracing Nature's page,
To ſoothe the pangs I felt.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The moſs-wove oaks that near my cave
And o'er its broken ſummit wave,

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Thoſe time-ſhook tow'rs, which all forſake,
And half of yon tranſlucent lake,

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: When ſhall my penitence and pray'rs
When ſhall my thorny bed of cares

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Nor let it ever backward look

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: Or thou! memorial croſs of God,
And bow my heart upon the ſod,

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Nor all her fountains cleanſe the ſteel

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Ah! let me eaſe it then, and ſpeak
What bitter griefs firſt bade me ſeek

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Near Cheviot Hills I drew the air
My mother was of preſence fair,

lg.head: X.
lg.l: To tend the flocks was my employ,
When my fond mother bleſt her boy,

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Yet oft with tears and ſmiles ſhe ſtrove,
And as I bent my knee,
She'd cry, "be juſter to thy love,
Than mine has been to me."

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: Yet little note of this I took,
And more admir'd my flow'r-bound crook,

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: The lowly cot, and ſhepherd's life,
Each night, each morn, ſhe prais'd;
And when they ſpoke of warlike ſtrife,

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: For now the wars of Paleſtine
While all admir'd the zeal divine,
And with his deeds were fraught.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: The glorious talk to me was good;
And as it fill'd my ear,
I ſeem'd to cleave the founding flood,

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: When, lo! the neighbouring Scots, a band
Ruſh'd like a whirlwind o'er the land,

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: By many an art my mother try'd
And ev'n her tears were vain.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: Each ſwain I bade renounce his crook;
And left them not a choice.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: No parle did either party uſe,
One ſought as men who'd all to loſe,

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: Day faintly purpled o'er the ſky
But ere our ſtubborn foes would fly,
The Sun his courſe had ran.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: Thus we retriev'd our fleecy ſtore,
And ſeem'd, I ween, to love them more,
For all the blows they coſt.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Not Richard's ſelf his warriors led
Than I for Aran's paſtures ſped,

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: As nigh I drew, the clouds did roll
The valley flam'd—and my full ſoul
Died in me at the fight.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: Another band of thoſe who roam
And while we fought to guard our home,
Had made that home a void.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: A while I wept, and duteous ſought
At length my heart, with vengeance fraught,

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: I rouz'd the ſwains who yet deplor'd
I turn'd my ſheep-hook to a ſword,

lg.head: XXVII.
lg.l: The ſavage Scots I ſwore t'annoy

lg.head: XXVIII.
lg.l: Between both lands ſtrong tow'rs I rear
One nation gaz'd on them with fear;

lg.head: XXIX.
lg.l: Around I ſtation'd many a band,
And ah! one day, by love's command,

lg.head: XXX.
lg.l: Her mien majeſtic ſeem'd to ſpeak
No roſe like that on her pure cheek
Blooms o'er the face of ſin.

lg.head: XXXI.
lg.l: Oh! not in grace the mountain pine
With her ſlight form could vye,
The blue that paints the arch divine
Was faint to her bright eye.

lg.head: XXXII.
lg.l: Like a rich group of yellow ſheaves,
Play'd on her breaſt—ſo Autumn leaves

lg.head: XXXIII.
lg.l: Awe-ſtruck, my ſoul imbib'd a flame
Nor dared I boldly aſk the name,

lg.head: XXXV.
lg.l: "From brutal hands I ſeek a friend,

lg.head: XXXVII.
lg.l: "Her ſum of days like his are ſpent,

lg.head: XXXIX.
lg.l: "That you yield him with care, and truth,

lg.head: XL.
lg.l: "So may the peace to him you give
"So crown'd with conqueſt may you live,

lg.head: XLI.
lg.l: "Ne'er ſhall ſhe vainly aſk my aid,

lg.head: XLII.
lg.l: "To yield thy Sire, with truth, and care,

lg.head: XLIII.
lg.l: "To horſe, to horſe, each vaſſal knight,

lg.head: XLIV.
lg.l: "A Youth her beauty well might ſnare,

lg.head: XLV.
lg.l: And ſoon my warriors o'er the waſte
The Lady in the centre plac'd,

lg.head: XLVI.
lg.l: Still as we journied on, I ſought,
T' impreſs myſelf on ev'ry thought,

lg.head: XLVII.
lg.l: And now my fears would often hint
And wiſer 'twere our truſt to ſtint,

lg.head: XLVIII.
lg.l: "Nor dare I ſcorn a father's ſway,

lg.head: L.
lg.l: "And ſure a fearful joy ſhe knows

lg.head: LI.
lg.l: "More fondly draws the heart's dear chain,
"Oh! the ſad charm, to know his pain

lg.head: LII.
lg.l: Fill'd with her love, ſooth'd with her hope,

lg.head: LIII.
lg.l: When now we reach'd fair Severn's ſide,
A mountain ſwell'd with verdant pride,

lg.head: LIV.
lg.l: As to the height we gaily wound,
Surpriz'd we heard the drum's fierce ſound,

lg.head: LV.
lg.l: Like ſhining ſwarms of bees, in arms
And pleaſure's notes, and war's alarms,

lg.head: LVI.
lg.l: When proud I did the Lady ſhew,—
More radiant than the vernal bow,
Heav'ns own bright pledge of peace,

lg.head: LVII.
lg.l: Her name, in various accents cried,
While the vaſt portals opening wide,

lg.head: LVIII.
lg.l: Forth ruſh'd, tumultuous as the wind,
But marching with their ſpears declin'd,

lg.head: LIX.
lg.l: At once, dividing to each ſide,
And as the ſwan floats with the tide,

lg.head: LX.
lg.l: The gift of health, an aged bloom,
And white his locks, as erſt the plume,

lg.head: LXI.
lg.l: The Maid oppreſs'd with tender pain,
And, than the hart more fleet,
Now graceful ſhot along the plain,

lg.head: LXII.
lg.l: Have you not ſeen the fragile roſe,
Droop with the gems of morn?
So fair the kneeling Virgin ſhews,

lg.head: LXIII.
lg.l: Have you not ſeen the purple vine

lg.head: LXIV.
lg.l: And faſt his tears would fall,

lg.head: LXV.
lg.l: "Thy ſafe return in peace, and health,
"Thy ſafe return doth ſpare my wealth,

lg.head: LXVI.
lg.l: He ſaid, and turning to a Knight,

lg.head: LXX.
lg.l: My ſoul, as with an ague ſhook,
At once both froze and burn'd;
When ſhe, not deigning him a look,

lg.head: LXXII.
lg.l: "Could I from duty have been won,
"I ſhould have call'd this Knight thy ſon,

lg.head: LXXIII.
lg.l: "Oh! think, tho' fortune freed his will,
"Oh! riſe above the thought of ill—

lg.head: LXXIV.
lg.l: "But tears, like falling drops on ſtone,

lg.head: LXXV.
lg.l: The Baron's eyes blaz'd thro' the ſnow
And red his haughty bluſhes glow,
While thus he ſpeaks his ire.

lg.head: LXXVI.
lg.l: "And who then art thou, nameleſs Youth?
"Which dyes thy cheek with nature's truth,

lg.head: LXXVII.
lg.l: "Where are the honors of thy line?
"Which thou preſum'ſt to blend with mine,

lg.head: LXXVIII.
lg.l: "Knowſt thou, the ſpoils of many a Knight
"Knowſt thou the lands within thy ſight,

lg.head: LXXIX.
lg.l: "Learn, Youth, to aſk ſome fit reward,
"And fame, and wealth, and high regard,

lg.head: LXXXI.
lg.l: "But let us prove this vaunted blood,

lg.head: LXXXII.
lg.l: "For while firm youth ſhall brace his hand,

lg.head: LXXXIII.
lg.l: "Come then, ye knights, your well-tried arms

lg.head: LXXXIV.
lg.l: Aloſt I wav'd my ſword of pow'r,
And like the Guard of Eden's bow'r,

lg.head: LXXXV.
lg.l: While thus we met, with equal ire,

lg.head: LXXXVI.
lg.l: Oh! if ye ever knew to melt
I need not paint the pangs I felt,

lg.head: LXXXVII.
lg.l: Oh! if ye ever yet have rag'd,
Ye well will gueſs the war we wag'd,

lg.head: LXXXVIII.
lg.l: The ſun unheeded veil'd his head,
While many a caſque was riv'n;
And that laſt darkneſs ſeem'd to ſpread,

lg.head: LXXXIX.
lg.l: Yet ſtill in mortal conflict join'd,
'Till oft, by heaven's wild fires, we find
A friend ſlain for a foe.

lg.head: XCI.
lg.l: But on the morn, at Ethel's word,

lg.head: XCII.
lg.l: My Knights, deſpoil'd of armor, peace
My ſword alone they dar'd not ſeize;

lg.head: XCIII.
lg.l: What then was all my early fame!
What then, alas! even virtue's flame!

lg.head: XCIV.
lg.l: Loſt to my heart its only joy,

lg.head: XCV.
lg.l: The bridal feaſt approach'd, the veſts
To many a fair were ſhewn,
Full was the Baron's hall of gueſts,

lg.head: XCVI.
lg.l: All hope now loſt, I wild aroſe,

lg.head: XCVII.
lg.l: A dreary eye around I caſt,
And own'd it as my knell.

lg.head: XCVIII.
lg.l: When lo! approaching faſt, the tread
I turn'd, and as by juſtice led,

lg.head: C.
lg.l: And long the vict'ry doubtful hung,

lg.head: CI.
lg.l: At length, between th' ill-jointed mail,
Faſt ruſh'd the ſtream of life, and pale

lg.head: CII.
lg.l: While ſighs of rage from his proud breaſt
A thouſand pangs his eye confeſt,

lg.head: CIII.
lg.l: "Call to your aid the pow'r divine,

lg.head: CV.
lg.l: "And left the charm of ev'ry eye

lg.head: CVIII.
lg.l: He groan'd aſſent—thro' all my frame

lg.head: CIX.
lg.l: He bent to earth his head:
"Oh do not more than kill me, boy!"

lg.head: CX.
lg.l: "Yet while I've ſtrength the truth to groan,
"Bid here the Monks, that I may own

lg.head: CXI.
lg.l: And forth the holy Fathers wound,

lg.head: CXII.
lg.l: And liſt with hallow'd zeal afar,

lg.head: CXIII.
lg.l: Before the croſs the dying Lord,
In ſilence firſt his God ador'd,

lg.head: CXIV.
lg.l: Then raiſing to the Monks his eyes,

lg.head: CXV.
lg.l: "If ſtruggling thus with ſhame and death,

lg.head: CXVI.
lg.l: "Inform my Liege, that led by pride,
"In early youth I choſe a bride,

lg.head: CXVII.
lg.l: "With impious zeal, the band I join'd
"And with falſe glory fir'd my mind,

lg.head: CXVIII.
lg.l: "With him a priſon's gloom I ſhar'd,

lg.head: CXIX.
lg.l: "While in our Northern wilds was born
"Has from its ſeat that being torn,

lg.head: CXX.
lg.l: "Since juſtly then, in flow'r of health,
"Oh may he give my heir my wealth,

lg.head: CXXI.
lg.l: "To ſave his ſoul from endleſs fire,

lg.head: CXXII.
lg.l: He died—nor had I time to think
On all I'd loſt, or won,—

lg.head: CXXIII.
lg.l: The buſy Monks remov'd the corſe,
When fraud effected, what nor force,

lg.head: CXXIV.
lg.l: And ſoon the hoſtile mountain ſcale,
Where now the gates flew wide.

lg.head: CXXV.
lg.l: The high-arch'd halls I ſafely paſt,
Where echo to the midnight blaſt
Sigh'd wild, and loud as me.

lg.head: CXXVIII.
lg.l: The ſnowy plumes appear to wave,
Defend the honors which they gave,

lg.head: CXXIX.
lg.l: On me all ſeem to turn their eyes
Then, like the rainbow's tranſient dyes,

lg.head: CXXX.
lg.l: Where tapers ſhed a quiv'ring gleam,

lg.head: CXXXI.
lg.l: With bold deſpair I thither paſt,
'Till ent'ring, with rude ſtep, the laſt,

lg.head: CXXXII.
lg.l: Careleſs ſhe view'd thoſe arms ſo fam'd,

lg.head: CXXXIII.
lg.l: "But Hymen's torch is quench'd in blood,

lg.head: CXXXVI.
lg.l: "Each bluſh which deepen'd on my cheek,
"Oh learn to think that paſſion weak,

lg.head: CXXXVII.
lg.l: "And when the laſt fond crimſon flies

lg.head: CXXXVIII.
lg.l: "Alas! ev'n now that hour is come—

lg.head: CXXXIX.
lg.l: While yet ſhe ſpoke, the roſeate hue,
Which on her ſoft cheek play'd,
And her bright eyes celeſtial blue

lg.head: CXL.
lg.l: As ſhe ev'n then were dead.

lg.head: CXLI.
lg.l: More cold, and cold, that heart now grew,
More ſlow, and ſlow, her breath ſhe drew,

lg.head: CXLII.
lg.l: And now, beyond the grief of thought—
She ſeem'd a beauteous ſtatue, wrought
To grace her own ſad tomb.

lg.head: CXLIII.
lg.l: O'er the fair form, tho' dead,
Fond fancy's wiſh, vain reaſon's boaſt,

lg.head: CXLIV.
lg.l: No voice its ſolitude could break—
Not ev'n her ſire's complaints could wake

lg.head: CXLV.
lg.l: Alas! to him who caus'd the grief,
A ſudden, and a long relief,

lg.head: CXLVI.
lg.l: The Monks Lord Albert's will aſſert—
When did they know a breaking heart

lg.head: CXLVII.
lg.l: To all theſe comforters my ſoul,

lg.head: CXLVIII.
lg.l: Wild as theſe woods, in them to mourn

lg.head: CXLIX.
lg.l: Oft on the hill, the hunters hear
And turn aſide with holy fear,

lg.head: CL.
lg.l: Ev'n the wild deer, with look profound,

lg.head: CLI.
lg.l: Catch life from my wild brain.—

lg.head: CLII.
lg.l: Full threeſcore times the froſts have bound
All ſtreams but from theſe eyes,
Since here my care-worn limbs firſt found

lg.head: CLIII.
lg.l: Years upon years thus ſlowly roll,
Since ev'n in ſleep my active ſoul

lg.head: CLIV.
lg.l: Dim are my days, and near the hour
When death at length is mine;
Which only can my bliſs reſtore,

lg.head: CLV.
lg.l: Ye generous poor, who ſend me bread,
Your little offspring find me dead,

lg.head: CLVI.
lg.l: Hide me in earth, and conſecrate
So may you ever 'ſcape the fate
